turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Floating interest rate.
turn.1: What is meant by bullet payment?
turn.2: A floating rate loan therefore may or may not incorporate a bullet payment.
turn.3: What are some examples of bullet payments?
turn.4: A customer borrows $25,000 from a bank; the terms of the loan are (six-month) LIBOR + 3.5%.
turn.5: What does it mean to the customer?
turn.6: At the time of issuing the loan, the LIBOR rate is 2.5%.
turn.7: What does it mean to the bank?
turn.8: For the first six months, the borrower pays the bank 6% annual interest: in this simplified case $750 for six months.
turn.9: What happens after the first six months?
turn.10: At the end of the first six months, the LIBOR rate has risen to 4%; the client will pay 7.5% (or $937.5) for the second half of the year.
turn.11: Is there anything else of note?
turn.12: At the beginning of the second year, the LIBOR rate has now fallen to 1.5%, and the borrowing costs are $500 for the following six months.
